thread.title: Creepy Caribbean: The region's spookiest haunts
thread.title_full: Creepy Caribbean: The region's spookiest haunts

title: Creepy Caribbean: The region's spookiest haunts
text:

(Photo: Cayman Islands Department of Tourism)
4 CONNECT 22 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE With its spirited history of pirates, haunted houses and witches who come back from the dead, the Caribbean is rife with spine-tingling ghost stories, paranormal sightings and devils that carry red and black pitchforks. If you're visiting around Halloween, leave the pumpkin pizzazz and trick or treating at home, put on your finest orange and black and check out our delightfully spooky itinerary.
Cayman Islands
You really have been to been to hell and back after rummaging around a macabre million-year old field dotted with jagged black limestone and dolomite rocks. Aptly called Hell, a pitchfork's throw from George Town in Grand Cayman, the horror hamlet is home to no more than 60 brave souls, a scattering of wayward lizards and blood red hibiscus blooms. Located in the West Bay district, geologists believe salt and lime deposits solidified the shells and skeletons of sea critters forming the pockmarked rockscape. You can't walk along the formation, but there are two platforms you can stand on for photo-taking. Hell got its name in the early 1930s, after a politician from England named Commissioner Cardinall tried to shoot a bird that was resting on the pointed black rocks. When he missed, he voiced his disappointment with a rather loud "Oh Hell" and the name stuck. Today, Hell is not only interesting to geologists and historians but also to tourists who stop by the Post Office to stamp a letter with the authentic Hell postmark and to meet and greet Ivan Farrington, resident island devil and owner of The Devil's Hangout Gift Shop . Sporting red horns on his head and carrying a black and red pitchfork, he likes to tell visitors that he's having "one helluva day" as he tosses his red cape over his shoulder. Halloween hokey, the gift shop stocks kitschy t-shirts that say 'If you don't like my attitude, go to Hell', hot sauces so hot they could melt the polar icecaps and Hell-branded mugs perfect for a cup of red hot spicy coffee.
Jamaica
<!--iframe-->
One of the grandest Great Houses in Jamaica is also the spookiest. Built in 1770, Rose Hall Plantation in Montego Bay was owned by John Palmer and his feisty British wife Annie. Her infamous black magic powers eventually led to John's demise and during her reign as mistress of the plantation, she reportedly did away with two more husbands and countless lovers. The so-called 'White Witch' was also allegedly quick with the whip; she was notorious for torturing her slaves in the dank dungeon. Believers will tell you her spirit still haunts the plantation house, which has been artfully restored with 18th-century furnishings. Daytime tours are offered from 9:15 a.m. to 5:15 p.m. but it's the candle–lit evening tours that start at 6:30 p.m. that are the creepiest. Informative guides take tour-goers through the plantation while recounting eerie tales about murder and mayhem guaranteed to elicit goosebumps from even the most skeptical. Keeping with the theme, the recommended rum cocktail in the dungeon tavern called Annie's Pub is the 'Witches Brew' that banishes the spirits of the ghosts that still flit about the mansion. Prices for both the day and night tour is USD$20 for adults and USD$10 for children (although if you're looking to avoid nightmares you may want to leave the kids with a babysitter back at the resort.)
Saba
Every Halloween, the tiny island of Saba goes (literally) batty. (Photo: Marco Di Gianvito)
Every Halloween, the tiny island of Saba (population: 2,000 people on five square miles) across the sea from St. Maarten goes (literally) batty. As part of the month-long Sea & Learn program held every year in October, bat biologist Fernando Simal takes brave souls on his Batman Hike up to the summit of Mount Scenery which is, indeed, quite scenic. Along the way, hikers explore bat dwellings in the rainforest like caves, crannies and trees and using a black light, bats and luminescent scorpions are easy to spot. As part of the island's bat monitoring program, bat fanatics eavesdrop on the ultrasonic bat-speak of the winged critters while observing their curious nocturnal antics. Starting after dark, the Batman Hike is free and fun for kids who don't mind being scared or want to be a bat scientist (or Batman) when they grow up. For those who prefer their bat learning on level ground, grab a seat at the Sea Witch Bar and Grill in Windwardside for 'Bats in the Caribbean', where the resident bat biologist lets you in on the secret world of bats.
Trinidad
On the southern slopes of the northern mountain range, it’s believed the ghost of Charles Joseph Count de Lopinot prowls his former home on stormy nights. (Photo: Trinidad and Tobago Tourism Development Company)
Deep in the rainforest of Trinidad in the village of Lopinot, there are plenty of bumps in the night at the Lopinot Estate . On the southern slopes of the northern mountain range, it's believed the ghost of Charles Joseph Count de Lopinot; a young knight who rose to the rank of Lieutenant-General in the French army, prowls his former home on stormy nights. Built in the 1700's as a cocoa plantation, it was there that the evil military man hung his slaves from a cashew tree in front of the estate. Visitors to the spooky home have seen his ghost ride a white horse to that same cashew tree and then disappear. Former employees of the plantation report hearing de Lopinot's footsteps inside the main house and seeing a glowing ball of fire by the river. The spine-chilling estate is now a museum with free guided tours from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Enter at your own risk.
Bermuda
<!--iframe-->
St. George's, one of the most storied neighborhoods in Bermuda, is also the most haunted. Twice a week, with special after dark Halloween tours on October 30 and October 31, Haunted History Walking Tours get underway from Kings Square with spooky storytellers leading the way. The tour wanders through narrow laneways like Shinbone Alley, named for the soldiers from the British Military Garrison who battered their shins after drunkenly crawling out of the taverns. With no more than 25 tour-goers in tow, costumed guides try not to disturb the ghosts who slumber beneath the ground where Bermuda was born in 1612. Tickets for the 75-minute half-mile walk are USD$30 per person, USD$25 for kids under 16 and those over 65 and can be ordered online HERE , or purchased at the St. George's Visitor Information Centre on King's Square. Beware: young kids (or grown-ups who frighten easily) may get jumpy along the way.
Aruba
For something spooky but less haunted, look towards Aruba's cave systems. Along the northern shore in the Arikok National Park, the light that seeps through the ceilings of the Guadiriki Cave make it one of the eeriest places on the island. (Photo: Aruba Tourism Authority)
Wedged between the coral cliffs above the Spanish Lagoon and across from the abandoned Balashi Gold Mill, the tapered canyon in Aruba known as Frenchman's Pass is home to ghostly spirits from a bygone era. As the story goes, pirates in 1620 tried to invade the island but were stopped in their tracks by Natives defending the Pass. The pirates tried to smoke their adversaries out of the cave but instead killed them with the toxic fumes. The deadly passage became known as 'Franse Pas' in French, 'Rooi Frances' in the local language of Papiamento and 'Frenchman's Pass' in English. Locals living near the pass say the lagoon is still haunted by the ghosts of the Natives, who can be heard wailing at night. For those who like to hunt spooks on the back of a bike, Aruba Motorcycle Tours takes riders through the Pass.
For something spooky but less haunted, look towards Aruba's cave systems. Along the northern shore in the Arikok National Park, the light that seeps through the ceilings of the Guadiriki Cave make it one of the eeriest places on the island. With two large chambers and stairs that lead up to the main entrance, the cave is also where you'll find forbidding looking bats that are actually quite harmless around human intruders. De Palm Tours offers excursions into the caves.
Haiti
Believers light candles in the sea to cleanse their souls, sacrifice animals to the spirits and communicate with the dead through trances. (Photo: Eduardo Munoz, Reuters)
Those shuffling staples in B-movies called zombies are actually one of the scariest beliefs in the Voodoo religion, which has been practiced in Haiti for three centuries. Believers light candles in the sea to cleanse their souls, sacrifice animals to the spirits and communicate with the dead through trances. For those curious about Voodoo, you'll shiver with delight at the Plaine du Nord Festival held in the summer on the border between the Massif de Nord Mountains and the Atlantic Ocean, where thousands come to take part in mass Voodoo rituals. For those in the Halloween mood, head to the colonial burial ground in the capital city of Port-au-Prince called the Grand Cemetery where the living are stopped dead in their tracks after coming face to face with corpses that reportedly stagger around the ghoulish graveyard at night.
Nevis
According to streetcorner lore, The Great House of Eden Brown on Nevis is haunted by the ghosts of a groom and his best man who killed each other during a wedding in 1822. (Photo: Ian G. Holyoak, Nevis Tourism Authority)
No one has lived at Eden Browne for more than 150 years. On the eastern side of the small isle across the channel from St. Kitts, there is good reason the estate has been empty for so long. According to streetcorner lore, The Great House near Butlers Village is haunted by the ghosts of a groom and his best man who killed each other during a wedding in 1822. The bloody duel and the heartbreak that followed for the would-be bride happened on the exact same day that the property was to be christened as Garden of Eden at Browne's Estate. The arranged marriage between Caroline James Beard and John Higgins was intended to bring together two prosperous families but it didn't end happily ever after. Believers say the mayhem and murder led to a curse that still hangs around the dilapidated estate. Tourists who pass by the rundown estate get the willies knowing the ghost of the groom's forlorn fiancée still roams the house and her sobbing still heard in the dead of night.
Barbados
The dead are anything but at rest in the cemetery of the Christ Church in the Barbados fishing village called Oistins. (Photo: visitbarbados.org)
The dead are anything but at rest in the cemetery of the Christ Church in the fishing village called Oistins. With more twists and turns than a Sherlock Holmes whodunit, legend has it each time the 19th-century Chase Vault with its two-foot thick coral and concrete walls was opened to bury another deceased family member, the coffins of Colonel Thomas Chase and his two young daughters mysteriously moved around, even after the crypt was sealed shut with a blue slab of marble at the entrance. When an investigation in 1820 offered no reasonable explanation for the moving coffins, they were buried in another location. The now-vacant vault still sits in the quiet church graveyard on the south coast and is the Halloween venue of choice for ghost hunters on a midnight stroll.
